notesStmt.note: A translation of: Tutte l'opere d'architettura.
Colophon, last leaf recto, reads "Printed at London, by Simon Stafford. 1611.".
Books 2-5 each have separate title page, foliation, and register. The title page to book 2 is printed on Â¹H2.

The woodcuts for the title-page borders and illustrations were first used in the Antwerp edition of 1553. They were later used in the 1606 edition in Dutch printed in Amsterdam by C. Claeszoon, who also printed them on sheets otherwise blank and shipped them to Basel, where letterpress in German was overprinted in 1608, and to London for the present edition. Thomas Snodham printed only the bifolium following the first title page (STC addendum).
Variant: "Printed by Robert Peake" blocked out on one or more of the title pages to books 1, 2, 4, or 5 (book 3 lacks imprint).
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Lacks the two leaves after first title page.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Â¶ The firÅ¿t Chapter.
div.p: HOw needfull and neceÅ¿Å¿ary the moÅ¿t Å¿ecret Art of Geometrie is for euery Artificer and Workeman, as thoÅ¿e that for a long time haue Å¿tudied and wrought without the Å¿ame can Å¿ufficiently witneÅ¿Å¿e, who Å¿ince that time haue attained vnto any knowledge of the Å¿aid Arte, doe not onely laugh and Å¿mile at their owne former Å¿implicities, but in trueth may very well acknowledge that all whatÅ¿oeuer had bene formerly done by them, was not worth the looking on.

Seeing then the learning of Architecture comprehendeth in it many notable Artes, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the Architector or workeman, Å¿hould firÅ¿t, or at the leaÅ¿t (if he cannot attaine vnto any more) know Å¿o much thereof, as that hee may vnderÅ¿tand the principles of Geometrie, that he may not be accompted amongÅ¿t the number of Å¿tone-Å¿poilers, who beare the name of workmen, and Å¿carce know how to make an anÅ¿were what a Point, Line, Plaine, or Body is, and much leÅ¿Å¿e can tell what harmonie or correÅ¿pondencie meaneth, but following after their owne minde, or other blinde conductors that haue vÅ¿ed to worke without rule or reaÅ¿on, they make bad worke, which is the cauÅ¿e of much vncut or vneuen workemanÅ¿hip which is found in many places.

Therfore Å¿eeing that Geometrie is the firÅ¿t degree of all good Art, to the end I may Å¿hew the Architector Å¿o much thereof, as that he may thereby be able with good Å¿kill, to giue Å¿ome reaÅ¿on of his worke. Touching the Å¿peculations of Euclides and other Authors, that haue written of Geometrie, I will leaue them, and onely take Å¿ome flowers out of their Garden, that therewith by the Å¿horteÅ¿t way that I can, I may entreat of diuers cutting through of Lines, with Å¿ome demonÅ¿trations, meaning Å¿o plainely and openly to Å¿et downe and declare the Å¿ame, both in writing and in figures, that euery man may both conceiue and vnderÅ¿tand them, aduertizing the Reader not to proceed to know the Å¿econd figure, before he hath well vnderÅ¿tood and found out the firÅ¿t, and Å¿o Å¿till proceeding, hee Å¿hall at laÅ¿t attaine vnto his deÅ¿ire.

div.p: AMong all the things that may bee made by mens hands, thereby to yÃ©eld admiration, pleaÅ¿ure to Å¿ight, and to content the Å¿antaÅ¿ies of men; I thinke it is placing of a Scene, as it is Å¿hewed to your Å¿ight, where a man in a Å¿mall place m â¢â¢ Å¿Ã©e built by Carpenters or MaÅ¿ons, Å¿kilfull in PerÅ¿pectiue worke, great Palaces, large Temples, and diuers HouÅ¿es, both neere and farre off; broad places filled with HouÅ¿es, long Å¿trÃ©ets croÅ¿t with other wayes: tryumphant Arches, high Pillars or Columnes, Piramides, ObeliÅ¿cens, and a thouÅ¿and fayre things and buildings, adorned with innumerable lights, great, middle Å¿ort, and Å¿mall, as you may Å¿Ã©e it placed in the Figure, which are Å¿o cunningly Å¿et out, that they Å¿hew foorth and repreÅ¿ent a number of the brighteÅ¿t Å¿tones; as Diamonds, Rubins, Saphirs, Smaragdes, Iacinthes, and Å¿uch like. And when occaÅ¿ion Å¿erueth, you Å¿hall by Arte Å¿Ã©e a God deÅ¿cending downe from Heauen; you alÅ¿o Å¿Ã©e Å¿ome Comets and Stars Å¿hoot in the Å¿kyes: then you Å¿Ã©e diuers perÅ¿onages come vpon the Stage, richly adorned with diuers Å¿trange formes and manners of Apparell both to daunce MoriÅ¿coes and play MuÅ¿icke. Sometimes you Å¿Ã©e Å¿trange beaÅ¿ts, wherein are men and children, leaping, running, & Tumbling, as thoÅ¿e kind of beaÅ¿ts vÅ¿e to doe, not without admiration of the beholders: which things, as occaÅ¿ion Å¿erueth, are Å¿o pleaÅ¿ant to mens eyes, that a man could not Å¿Ã©e fairer made with mens hands. But for that we are entred into another maner of PerÅ¿pectiue worke, therefore I will Å¿peake more at large thereof. This PerÅ¿pectiue worke wherof I wil Å¿peake, although it be contrary to thoÅ¿e rules which are Å¿hewed before, becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e aforeÅ¿ayd are imagined to be vpon a Å¿lat wall: and this other rule becauÅ¿e it is materiall and imboÅ¿Å¿ed or rayÅ¿ed outward, therefore it is reaÅ¿on we obÅ¿erue another rule therein, according to common cuÅ¿tome. FirÅ¿t, you muÅ¿t make a Scaffold, which muÅ¿t bee as high as a mans eye will reach, looking directly for ward; for the firÅ¿t part thereof which is marked C. But the other part behind it, whereon the HouÅ¿es Å¿tand, you muÅ¿t rayÅ¿e vp behind againÅ¿t the wall at leaÅ¿t a ninth part thereof, that is, you muÅ¿t deuide the playne Stage or Scaffold in nine parts; and then you muÅ¿t make the Scaffold higher by a ninth part behind: then before at B. which muÅ¿t be very euen & Å¿trong becauÅ¿e of the MoriÅ¿ed dancers. This hanging downward of the Scaffold, I haue found by experience to be very pleaÅ¿ing, for in Vincente which is as Å¿umptuous and rich a Towne as any in all Italy; there I made a Theater and a Stage of wood, then the which, I thinke, there was neuer a greater made in our time, in regard of the wonderfull Å¿ights that there were Å¿cene, as of Wagons, Elephants and other MoriÅ¿coes. There I ordained, that before the hanging Scene there Å¿hould be a Scaffold made by water compaÅ¿Å¿e, which Scaffold was 12. foot broad, and 60. foot long, according to the place wherin it Å¿tood; which I found to be very pleaÅ¿ing and fit for Å¿hew. This firÅ¿t Scaffold, becauÅ¿e it was right, therefore the pauement therof muÅ¿t not obey the HoriÅ¿on, but the Quadrants, whereof on euery Å¿ide were foure Å¿quare, from whence at the beginning of the riÅ¿ing Scaffold B. all the Quadrans went to the outtermoÅ¿t HoriÅ¿on O. which with their due diÅ¿tances do Å¿horten very well. And for th â¢â¢ Å¿ome men haue placed the HoriÅ¿on of this Sciographies againÅ¿t the wall right aboue the Scaffold, whereby it Å¿Ã©emeth the HouÅ¿es runne all in one; therefore I determined to place the HoriÅ¿on before the doore, which pleaÅ¿ed me Å¿o well, that I vÅ¿ed the Å¿ame kind of order in all theÅ¿e kind of works: and Å¿o I counÅ¿ell thoÅ¿e that take pleaÅ¿ure in Å¿uch Arts, to vÅ¿e and eÅ¿teeme this way for the beÅ¿t, as I will Å¿hew in this Figure following, and haue alÅ¿o declared in the profill of the Theater and Scene.

And becauÅ¿e the preparation for Comedies are done in thrÃ©e Å¿orts, that is, Comical, Tragical and Satiricall; I will firÅ¿t entreat of the Comicall, whereof the HouÅ¿es muÅ¿t be made as if they were for common or ordinarie people, which for the moÅ¿t part muÅ¿t be made vnder roofes in a Hall, which at the end thereof hath a chamber for the pleaÅ¿ure or eaÅ¿e of ye perÅ¿onages: and there it is that the ground of the Scaffold is made (as I Å¿aid and Å¿hewed before) in the profil. Therefore C. is the firÅ¿t part being the flat Scaffold; and Å¿uppoÅ¿e that each Quadran containeth two foote on eyther Å¿ide, Å¿o Å¿hal they vpon the hanging Scaffold before on the BaÅ¿e be alÅ¿o two foot broad, which is marked B. And (as I Å¿ayd before) my meaning is not to place the HoriÅ¿on hereof againÅ¿t the backe behind in the Scaffold, but as farre as it is from the beginning of the pauement B. to the wall, Å¿o farre I would alÅ¿o that men Å¿hall paÅ¿Å¿e behinde through the wall, and Å¿o Å¿hall all the houÅ¿es and other things Å¿how better in the Å¿hortening: and when by conuenient diÅ¿tances you haue drawne all the Quadrans towards the HoriÅ¿on, & Å¿hortened them, then you muÅ¿t Å¿horten the houÅ¿es right with the foure Å¿quare Å¿tones; which houÅ¿es are the great lines marked vpon the ground, aÅ¿well for thoÅ¿e that Å¿tand vpright, as thoÅ¿e that Å¿horten. All Å¿uch houÅ¿es I alwayes made of Å¿pars, or rafter or laths, couered with linnin cloth; making doores and windowes, both before and in the Å¿hortening, as occaÅ¿ion fell out. I haue alÅ¿o made Å¿ome things of halfe planks of wood, which were great helpe to the Paynters to Å¿et out things at life. All the Å¿paces froÌ the backe to the wall marked A. Å¿hall be for the perÅ¿onages, to the which end the hindermoÅ¿t backe in the middle Å¿hall Å¿tand at the leaÅ¿t two foot from the wall, that the perÅ¿onages may goe from the one Å¿ide to the other, and not be Å¿Ã©ene. Then you muÅ¿t rayÅ¿e a termination at the beginning of the pauement B. which Å¿hall be the poynt L. and from thence to the HoriÅ¿on there Å¿halbe a line drawne, as it is marked in the profil with prickes, which Å¿hall be of like height; and where that toucheth the hindermoÅ¿t backe of the Scene or Scaffold, there the HoriÅ¿on of that backe Å¿hall Å¿tand: and that HoriÅ¿on Å¿hall Å¿erue onely for that backe. But if you Å¿tretch a corde or any other thing to the termination L. then you may faÅ¿ten a thread to it, to thruÅ¿t backward or forward, to vÅ¿e it out of the Å¿tedfaÅ¿t HoriÅ¿on, & all the Ortographie of the houÅ¿es before. But the HoriÅ¿on which goeth through the wall, Å¿hall Å¿erue for all the Å¿hortening Å¿ides of the houÅ¿es: and for that men Å¿hould breake the wall, if they would vÅ¿e all this HoriÅ¿on in groÅ¿Å¿e, which may not bee done, therefore I haue alwayes made a Å¿mall modell of wood and Paper iuÅ¿t of the Å¿ame bignes, and by the Å¿ame modell Å¿et it downe in groÅ¿Å¿e, from piece to piece. But this way will fall out hard for Å¿ome men to vnderÅ¿tand, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to worke by models and experiments, and by Å¿tudie a man Å¿hall Å¿ind the way: and for that a man can hardly finde any Halls how great Å¿oeuer, wherein he can place a Theater without imperfection and impediment; therefore to follow Antiquities, according to my power and abilitie, I haue made all Å¿uch parts of theÅ¿e Theaters, as may Å¿tand in a Hall. Therefore the part marked D. Å¿hall be the poÅ¿t Å¿cene, and the circular place marked E. Å¿hall bee the OrcheÅ¿tra: round about this OrcheÅ¿tra Å¿hall be the places for the nobleÅ¿t perÅ¿onages to Å¿it, marked F. The firÅ¿t Å¿teps marked G. for the nobleÅ¿t women to Å¿it vpon. The place H. is a way, Å¿o is the part marked I. In the middle betwÃ©ene theÅ¿e degrÃ©es are Å¿ â¢ eps the eaÅ¿ier to goe vp. The places marked K. muÅ¿t bee made Å¿o great backward as the Hall will afford, which is made Å¿omewhat Å¿looping, that the people may Å¿ee out ou â¢â¢

TOuching the diÅ¿poÅ¿iton of Theaters and other Scenes, concerning the grounds thereof, I haue Å¿poken Å¿ufficiently; now I will Å¿peake of the Scene in PerÅ¿pectiue worke: and for that Scenes are made of thrÃ©e Å¿orts, that is, Comical, to play Comedies on, Tragicall, for Tragedies, and Satiricall for Satirs. This firÅ¿t Å¿hall be Comicall, whereas the houÅ¿es muÅ¿t be flight for Citizens, but Å¿pecially there muÅ¿t not want a brawthell or bawdy houÅ¿e, and a great Inne, and a Church; Å¿uch things are of neceÅ¿Å¿tie to be therein. How to rayÅ¿e theÅ¿e houÅ¿es from the ground is Å¿ufficiently expreÅ¿Å¿ed, and how you Å¿hall place the HoriÅ¿on: neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, that you may be the better inÅ¿tructed (touching the former of theÅ¿e houÅ¿es) I haue here Å¿et downe a Figure, for Å¿atiÅ¿faction of thoÅ¿e that take pleaÅ¿ure therein; but becauÅ¿e this Figure is Å¿o Å¿mall, therein I could not obÅ¿erue all the meaÅ¿ures, but refer them to inuention, that thereby you may chuÅ¿e or make houÅ¿es which Å¿hew well, as an open Gallery, or lodge through the which you may Å¿Ã©e an other houÅ¿e. The hangings ouer or Å¿hooting out, Å¿how well in Å¿hortening worke, and Å¿ome Cornices cut out at the ends; accompanied with Å¿ome others that are painted, Å¿how well in worke: Å¿o doe the houÅ¿es which haue great bearing out, like lodgings or Ch â¢â¢ nbers for men, and eÅ¿pecially aboue all things, you muÅ¿t Å¿et the Å¿maleÅ¿t houÅ¿es before, that you may Å¿Ã©e other houÅ¿es ouer or aboue them, as you Å¿Ã©e it here aboue the bawdy houÅ¿e: for if you place the greateÅ¿t before, and the reÅ¿t behind Å¿till leÅ¿Å¿en, th â¢ n the place of the Scene would not be Å¿o well filled, and although theÅ¿e things vpon the one Å¿ide be made all vpon one floore: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, for that you place great part of the lights in the middle, hanging ouer the Scene or Scaffold, therefore it would Å¿tand better if the floore in the midÅ¿t were taken away, and all the roundels and Quadrans which you Å¿Ã©e in the Buildings, they are artificiall lights cutting through, of diuers colors; which to make, I will Å¿hew the manner in the laÅ¿t of this Booke. The windowes which Å¿tand before, were good to be made of GlaÅ¿Å¿e or Paper, with light behind them. But if I Å¿hould here write all that I know to Å¿erue for this worke, it would be ouerlong to rehearÅ¿e; therefore I referre that to the wit and diÅ¿cretion of thoÅ¿e that exerciÅ¿e and practiÅ¿e themÅ¿elue â¢ heerein.

HOuÅ¿es for Tragedies, muÅ¿t bee made for great perÅ¿onages, for that actions of loue, Å¿trange aduentures, and cruell murthers, (as you reade in ancient and moderne Tragedies) happen alwayes in the houÅ¿es of great Lords, Dukes, Princes, and Kings. Therefore in Å¿uch caÅ¿es you muÅ¿t make none but Å¿tately houÅ¿es, as you Å¿Ã©e it hore in this Figure; wherein (for that it is Å¿o Å¿mal) I could make no Princely Pallaces: but it is Å¿ufficient for the workeman to Å¿Ã©e the manner thereof, whereby he may helpe himÅ¿elfe as time and place Å¿erueth: and (as I Å¿ayde in the Comicall) hee muÅ¿t alwayes Å¿tudy to pleaÅ¿e the eyes of the beholders, and forget not himÅ¿elfe Å¿o much as to Å¿et a Å¿mall building in Å¿tead of a great, for the reaÅ¿ons aforeÅ¿ayd. And for that I haue made all my Scenes of laths, couered with linnen, yet Å¿ometime it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make Å¿ome things riÅ¿ing or boÅ¿Å¿ing out; which are to bee made of wood, like the houÅ¿es on the left Å¿ide, whereof the Pillars, although they Å¿horten, Å¿tand all vpon one BaÅ¿e, with Å¿ome Å¿tayres, all couered ouer with cloth, the Cornices bearing out, which you muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue to the middle part: But to giue place to the Galleries, you muÅ¿t Å¿et the other Å¿hortening Cloth Å¿omewhat backwards, and make a cornice aboue it, as you Å¿ee: and that which I Å¿peake of theÅ¿e Buildings, you muÅ¿t vnderÅ¿tand of all the reÅ¿t, but in the Buildings which Å¿tand far backward the Painting worke, muÅ¿t Å¿upplie the place by Å¿hadowes without any bearing out: touching the artificiall lights, I haue Å¿poken thereof in the Comicall works. All that you make aboue the Roofe Å¿ticking out, as Chimneyes, Towers, Piramides, ObliÅ¿ces, and other Å¿uch like things or Images; you muÅ¿t make them all of thin bords, cut out round, and well colloured: But if you make any flat Buildings, they muÅ¿t Å¿tand Å¿omewhat farre inward, that you may not Å¿ee them on the Å¿ides. In theÅ¿e Scenes, although Å¿ome haue painted perÅ¿onages therein like Å¿upporters, as in a Gallery, or doore, as a Dog, Cat, or any other beaÅ¿ts: I am not of that opinion, for that Å¿tandeth too long without Å¿tirring or moouing; but if you make Å¿uch a thing to lie Å¿lÃ©eping, that I hold withall. You may alÅ¿o make Images, HiÅ¿tories, or Fables of Marble, or other matter againÅ¿t a wall; but to repreÅ¿ent the life, they ought to Å¿tirre. In the latter end of this Booke I will Å¿hew you how to make them.

THe Satiricall Scenes are to repreÅ¿ent Satirs, wherein you muÅ¿t place all thoÅ¿e things that bee rude and ruÅ¿ticall, as in ancient Satire they were made plaine without any reÅ¿pect, whereby men might vnderÅ¿tand, that Å¿uch things were referred to RuÅ¿h call people, which Å¿et all things out rudely and plainely: for which cauÅ¿e Vitruuius Å¿peaking of Scenes, Å¿aith, they Å¿hould be made with TrÃ©es, Rootes, Herbs, Hils and Flowres, and with Å¿ome countrey houÅ¿es, as you Å¿Ã©e them here Å¿et downe. And for that in our dayes theÅ¿e things were made in Winter, when there were but fewe grÃ©ene TrÃ©es. Herbs and Flowres to be found; then you muÅ¿t make theÅ¿e things of Silke, which will be more commendable then the naturall things themÅ¿elues: and as in other Scenes for Comedies or Tragedies, the houÅ¿es or other artificiall things are painted, Å¿o you muÅ¿t make TrÃ©es, Hearbs, and other things in theÅ¿e; & the more Å¿uch things coÅ¿t, the more they are eÅ¿teemed, for they are things which Å¿tately and great perÅ¿ons doe, which are enemies to nigardlineÅ¿Å¿e. This haue I Å¿Ã©ene in Å¿ome Scenes made by Ieronimo Genga, for the pleaÅ¿ure and delight of his lord and patron FranciÅ¿co Maria, Duke of Vrbin: wherein I Å¿aw Å¿o great liberalitie vÅ¿ed by the Prince, and Å¿o good a conceit in the workeman, and Å¿o good Art and proportion in things therein repreÅ¿ented, as euer I Å¿aw in all my life before. Oh good Lord, what magnificence was there to be Å¿Ã©ene, for the great number of TrÃ©es and Fruits, with Å¿undry Herbes and Flowres, all made of fine Silke of diuers collors. The water courÅ¿es being adorned with Frogs, Snailes, TortuÅ¿es, Toads, Adders, Snakes, and other beaÅ¿ts: Rootes of Corrale, mother of Pearle, and other Å¿hels layd and thruÅ¿t through betwÃ©ene the Å¿tones, with Å¿o many Å¿euerall and faire things, that if I Å¿hould declare them all, I Å¿hould not haue time inough. I Å¿peake not of Satirs, Nimphes, Mer-maids, diuers monÅ¿ters, and other Å¿trange beaÅ¿tes, made Å¿o cunningly, that they Å¿Ã©emed in Å¿hew as if they went and Å¿tirred, according to their manner. And if I were not deÅ¿irous to be briefs, I would Å¿peake of the coÅ¿tly apparel of Å¿ome Shepheards made of cloth of gold, and of Silke, cunningly mingled with Imbrothery: I would alÅ¿o Å¿peake of Å¿ome FiÅ¿hermen, which were no leÅ¿Å¿e richly apparelled then the others, hauing Nets and Angling-rods, all gilr: I Å¿hould Å¿peake of Å¿ome Countrey mayds and Nimphes careleÅ¿ly apparelled without pride, but I leaue all theÅ¿e things to the diÅ¿cretion and conÅ¿ideration of the indicious workeman; which Å¿hall make all Å¿uch things as their paitcons Å¿erue them, which they muÅ¿t worke after their owne deuiÅ¿es, and neuer take care what it Å¿hall coÅ¿t.

div.head: Of Artificiall lights of the Scenes.
div.p: I PromiÅ¿ed in the TreatiÅ¿e of Scenes to Å¿et downe the manner how to make theÅ¿e lights Å¿hining through, of diuers collours, & firÅ¿t I will Å¿peake of a Å¿ure collour which is like to a Zaphir, and yet Å¿omewhat fayrer. Take a piece of Salamoniacke, and put it into a Barbers BaÅ¿en, or Å¿uch like thing, and put water into it: then bruÅ¿e and cruÅ¿h the Salamoniacke Å¿oftly therein, till it be all molten, alwayes putting more water vnto it, as you deÅ¿ire to haue it light or Å¿ad collour; which done, if you will haue it fayre and cleare, then Å¿traine it through a fine cloth into an other veÅ¿Å¿ell, and then it will be a cleare CeleÅ¿tiall blew, whereof you may make diuers kinds of blew with water. Will you make an Emerauld collour, then put Å¿ome Saffron as you will haue it pale or high colloured; for heere it is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary to preÅ¿cribe you any weight or meaÅ¿ure, for that experience will teach you bow to doe it. If you will make a Rubbie collour, if you bee in a place where you may haue red Wine. then you nÃ©ed not vÅ¿e any other thing; but to make it pall with water, us need requireth: but if you can get no wine, then take Brazill beaten to powder, & put it into a Kettell of water with Allum, let it Å¿Ã©ethe, and Å¿kum it well; then Å¿trayne it, and vÅ¿e it with water and Vinneger. If you will counterfeit a Ballayes, you muÅ¿t make it of red and white Wine mingled together; but white Wine alone will Å¿howe like a Topas or a CriÅ¿olite? The Conduit or common water being Å¿trayned, will be like a Diamond, and to doe this well, you muÅ¿t vpon a glaÅ¿Å¿ie ground frame certaine points or tablets, and fill them with water. The manner to Å¿et theÅ¿e Å¿hining collours in their places, in thus, Behind the painted houÅ¿e wherein theÅ¿e painted collours Å¿hall Å¿tand, you muÅ¿t Å¿et a thin board, cut out in the Å¿ame manner that theÅ¿e lights Å¿hall be placed, whether it be round or Å¿quare, cornerd or o â¢â¢ le, like an Egge; and behind the Å¿ame board there Å¿hall be another Å¿tronger board layd flat behind them, for the bottels and other manner of glaÅ¿Å¿es with theÅ¿e waters to Å¿tand in, muÅ¿t be placed againÅ¿t the holes, as it Å¿hall neceÅ¿Å¿arily fall out, but they muÅ¿t be Å¿et faÅ¿t, leÅ¿t they fall with leaping and dancing of the MoriÅ¿coes. And behind the glaÅ¿Å¿es you muÅ¿t Å¿et great Lampes, that the light may alÅ¿o be Å¿tedfaÅ¿t: and if the bottels or other veÅ¿Å¿els of glaÅ¿Å¿e on the Å¿ide where the light Å¿tands were flat, or rather hollow, it would Å¿how the clearer, and the collours moÅ¿t excellent and fayre; the like muÅ¿t be done with the holes on the Å¿hortening Å¿ide: But if you nÃ©ed a great light to Å¿how more then the reÅ¿t, then Å¿et a torch behind, and behind the torch a bright BaÅ¿on; the brightnes whereof will Å¿hew like the beames of the Sunne. You may alÅ¿o make glaÅ¿Å¿e of all collours and formes, Å¿ome foure Å¿quare, Å¿ome with croÅ¿Å¿es, & any other forme with their light behind them. Now all the lights Å¿eruing for the collours, Å¿hal not be ye Å¿ame which muÅ¿t light the Scene, for you muÅ¿t haue a great number of torches before the Scene. You may alÅ¿o place certaine candleÅ¿tickes aboue the Scene with great candles therein, and aboue the candleÅ¿ticks you may place Å¿ome veÅ¿Å¿els with water, wherein you may put a piece of Camphir, which burning, will Å¿how a very good light, and Å¿mell well. Sometime it may chance that you muÅ¿t make Å¿ome thing or other which Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme to burne, which you muÅ¿t wet throughly with excellent good Aquauite; and Å¿etting it on fire with a candle it will burne all ouer: and although I could Å¿peake more of theÅ¿e fires, yet this Å¿hal Å¿uffice for this time; & I will Å¿peake of Å¿ome things that are pleaÅ¿ing to the beholders. The while that the Scene is emptie of perÅ¿onages, then the workman muÅ¿t haue certaine Figures or formes ready of Å¿uch greatnes as the place where they muÅ¿t Å¿tand, will afford them to be, which muÅ¿t be made of paÅ¿Å¿e board, cut out round and paynted, Å¿ignifiing Å¿uch things as you will, which Figures muÅ¿t leane againÅ¿t a rule or lath of wood, croÅ¿Å¿e ouer the Scene where any gate, doore, or way is made, and there Å¿ome one or other behind the doore muÅ¿t make the. Figures paÅ¿Å¿e along, Å¿ometime in forme of MuÅ¿itions with inÅ¿truments, and Å¿ome like Å¿ingers; and behind the Scene Å¿ome muÅ¿t play on, vpon certaine inÅ¿truments and Å¿ing alÅ¿o: Å¿ometime you muÅ¿t make a number of foote men and horÅ¿emen going about with Trumpets, Phifes and Drummes, at which time you muÅ¿t play with Drumbes, Trumpets and Phifes, &c. very Å¿oftly behind, which will kÃ©epe the peoples eyes occupied, and content them well. If it be requiÅ¿ite to make a Planet or any other thing to paÅ¿Å¿e along in the Ayre, it muÅ¿t bee framed and cut out of paÅ¿te-board; then in the hindermoÅ¿t and backe part of the houÅ¿es of the Scene, there muÅ¿t be a piece of wire drawne aboue in the roofe of the houÅ¿e and made faÅ¿t with certain rings behind to the paÅ¿te-board painted with a Planet or any other thing that Å¿halbe drawne Å¿oftly by a man with a blacke thrÃ©ed from one end to the other, but it muÅ¿t be farre from mens Å¿ight, that neither of the thrÃ©eds may bee Å¿Ã©ene. Sometime you Å¿hall haue occaÅ¿ion to Å¿hew thunder and lightning as the play requireth; then you muÅ¿t make thunder in this manner: commonly all Scenes are made at the end of a great Hall, whereas vÅ¿ually there is a Chamber aboue it, wherein you muÅ¿t roule a great Bullet of a Cannon or of Å¿ome other great Ordinance, and then counterfeit Thunder. Lightning muÅ¿t be made in this maner, there muÅ¿t be a man placed behind the Scene or Scaffold in a high place with a boxe in his hand, the couer whereof muÅ¿t be full with holes, and in the middle of that place there Å¿hall be a burning candle placed, the boxe muÅ¿t be filled with powder of vernis or Å¿ulphire, and caÅ¿ting his hand with the boxe vpwards the powder flying in the candle, will Å¿hew as if it were lightning. But touching the beames of the lightning, you muÅ¿t draw a piece of wyre ouer the Scene, which muÅ¿t hang downewards, whereon you muÅ¿t put a Å¿quib conered ouer with pure gold or Å¿hining lattin which you will: and while the Bullet is rouling, you muÅ¿t Å¿hoote of Å¿ome piece of Ordinance, and with the Å¿ame giuing fire to the Å¿quibs, it will worke the effect which is deÅ¿ired. It would be ouerlong if I Å¿hould Å¿peake of all things which are to be vÅ¿ed in theÅ¿e affaires, therefore I will leaue Å¿peaking of PerÅ¿pectiue things.

div.p: ALthough diuers Authors write many Å¿trange things touching Architecture, as the Egyptians, the people of AÅ¿ia and Grecia, with diuers other nations, and haue left them for our example, Å¿o that reading them, we may Å¿ufficiently Å¿atisfie our cares, and fill them with the greatneÅ¿Å¿e thereof, that is, touching the length, bredth and depth, that certaine places haue contained; yet we can not Å¿atisfie our eyes, nor the deÅ¿ire we haue to Å¿ee Å¿uch incredible works, vnleÅ¿se it had beene our hap to haue the contemplation thereof, for that the reliques of Å¿uch works are almoÅ¿t, or for the moÅ¿t part vtterly defaced; or vnleÅ¿Å¿e we might haue Å¿eene them drawne in propertion vnto our eyes, as in this Booke we may not onely read, what the Romanes at the laÅ¿t, after other nations had built, but alÅ¿o the Å¿ame Authors haue Å¿et downe vnto vs in Figure (as you may Å¿ee them here) piece by piece not only how many rods, ells feet & palmes, but alÅ¿o the minutes thereof, and what compas they contained, all perfectly deÅ¿cribed. And although it was no part of my intent, to tranÅ¿late this Booke of Antiquities of Rome into our mother tongue, regarding the barrenneÅ¿Å¿e of our language; or peraduenture Å¿uch as Å¿tudie or fauour the Å¿ame, are all too few to defray my charges therein: yet I haue not refrained to doe it, being thereunto compelled by the great works of the forification of the City of Andwerp, and other great places; and for this cauÅ¿e Å¿pecially, that euery man that wondreth at the greatnes thereof, which was made with moÅ¿t great coÅ¿t & charges, may hereby Å¿ee and conÅ¿ider, yea how much greater, & needles charges (to be compared vnto this) the Romanes (not Å¿peaking of other nation) haue in time paÅ¿t beÅ¿towed, in making of ObeliÅ¿ces, Piramides, Thermes, Theaters, Amphitheaters, tryumphant Arches, and many more Å¿uch like things, which Å¿erued only for pleaÅ¿ure & tryumph: whereby it is to be preÅ¿umed, that they would haue made the fortifications of Å¿uch Cities or Townes, made for the Å¿afety of the Land, far better then they now are. Now it is to be noted, that all, whatÅ¿oeuer the Romanes haue made, doth not wholly agree with Vitruuius rules, Å¿o that many which haue counterfeyted theÅ¿e, and Å¿uch like peeces of worke, haue thereby beene abuÅ¿ed and deceiued: for Å¿ome would hardly beleeue, that in thoÅ¿e dayes (as well as at this time) all maner of workemen were one better then another, which many, vnawares and vnÅ¿kilfully do many things, which good Antiquities would willingly not Å¿uffer, hereof they Å¿hall find good inÅ¿tructions in this Booke (and they may learne, if they will read it) how to diÅ¿cerne good from bad; whereunto the former printed fourth Booke is Å¿pecially made: for in it the whole quantity of the meaÅ¿ures is contayned, as in the EpiÅ¿tle of the Å¿ayd Booke it is promiÅ¿ed. So in this third Booke, you Å¿hall not onely find, firÅ¿t the Ichnographia, and then after the Orthographyes, with part of the Sciographies of the moÅ¿t famous Antiquityes of Rome, Italy, and Å¿ome of other places, but alÅ¿o of the moÅ¿t excellent buyldings in our dayes, Å¿pecially thoÅ¿e that are made by Bramant. So that the Reader being well inÅ¿tructed in the aforeÅ¿ayd fourth Booke, where all the Orders are well Å¿et foorth and declared, he may of himÅ¿elfe iudge what is well or ill made, that at one time a man may, without any further labour, make a good and incorrigible peece of worke.

div.head: The third Booke of Antiquitie.
The fourth Chapter.
div.p: AMong all the ancient building to bee Å¿eene in Rome, I am of opinion, that the Pantheon (for one piece of worke alone) is the fayreÅ¿t, wholeÅ¿t, and beÅ¿t to be vnderÅ¿tood; and is Å¿o much the more wonderfull then the reÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e it hath Å¿o many members, which are all Å¿o correÅ¿pondent one to the other, that whoÅ¿oeuer beholdeth it, taketh great pleaÅ¿ure therein, which proceedeth from this, that the excellent workeman, which inuented it, choÅ¿e the perfiteÅ¿t forme, that is, the round forme, whereby it is vÅ¿ually called, Our Lady of the Round: for within, it is as high as it is broad. And it may be, that the Å¿ayd workeman, conÅ¿idering, that all things proceeding orderly, haue a principall and onely head, whereon the nether parts depend, was of opinion, that this piece of worke Å¿hould haue onely but one light, and that, in the higheÅ¿t part thereof, that it might Å¿pread abroad in all places alike, as in effect you Å¿ee it doth: for beÅ¿ides other things which haue their perfect light, there are Å¿ixe Chappels, which (for that they Å¿tand within the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of the wall) Å¿hould be darke, yet they haue their due light, by the meanes of Å¿ome drawing windowes, aboue in the top of the Å¿ayd Chappels, which giue them Å¿econd light, taken from the vppermoÅ¿t hole, Å¿o that there is not any Å¿mall thing in them, but it receiueth a part of the light, (and this is not made without great iudgement:) for this Temple, in old time, being dedicated to all the gods, by which meanes there Å¿tood many Images in it, (which the diuers Tabernacles, Seates, and Å¿mall windowes Å¿hew) it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary that euery one had his due light. Wherefore Å¿uch as take pleaÅ¿ure to make Images, and other imboÅ¿Å¿ed or grauen worke, muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, that Å¿uch a Cabinet Å¿hould haue his light from aboue, that euery one, Å¿tanding in his place, neede not looke for light to Å¿ee, but that they may bee Å¿eene altogether at one time. But to come to my firÅ¿t Å¿peach: For that the Pantheon Å¿eemeth vnto me to be the perfecteÅ¿t peece of worke that euer I Å¿aw, therefore I thought it good to Å¿et it firÅ¿t in the beginning of this Booke, and for a principall head of all other peeces of worke. The founder of this Temple (as Plinie writeth in more then one place) was Marcus Agrippa, to accompliÅ¿h AuguÅ¿tus CaeÅ¿ars laÅ¿t will, who being intercepted by death, could not finiÅ¿h it: and Å¿o it was built about foureteene yeeres after the byrth of our Lord, which is about 5203. yeeres from the beginning of the world.

In this Temple (as Pliny writeth) the Capitals were of Copper; and hee writeth alÅ¿o, that Diogenes, the Image-maker of Athens, made the excellent Caracters in the Pillars, and that the Images placed aboue the FronteÅ¿picium were much commended, although by the highneÅ¿Å¿e of the place they could not be Å¿o well diÅ¿cerned. This Temple was conÅ¿umed with lightening, and burnt, about the 12. yeere of the raigne of the Emperour Traian, which was about 113. yeeres after the byrth of ChriÅ¿t, and in the 5311. yeere of the creation of the world: and Lucius Septimus Seuerus, and Marcus Aurelius Antonius, repayred it agayne, with all the Ornaments thereto belonging, as it appeareth in the Architraue of the Å¿ayd frame: which Ornaments, you muÅ¿t preÅ¿ume, were all new made, otherwiÅ¿e the Caracters of Diogenes would Å¿till haue bene Å¿eene there. But in truth, the workman that made it, was very iudicious and conÅ¿tant; for that he proportioned the members thereof very iudiciouÅ¿ly to the body, and would not Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e the worke with many cuttings: but as I will Å¿hew, when time Å¿erueth, how to place and deuide them excellent well. AlÅ¿o, in all the worke, hee hath obÅ¿erued the worke of Corinth, and would mixe no other with it: and withall, the meaÅ¿ures of all the members are as well obÅ¿erued as euer I Å¿aw or meaÅ¿ured in any other peece of worke, whereby we may call this Temple an example of workemanÅ¿hip. But leauing this matter (for that it giueth the workeman little, or no inÅ¿truction to the purpoÅ¿e) I will proceede to the particular meaÅ¿ures: and that I may goe forward orderly in theÅ¿e Antiquities, the firÅ¿t Figure Å¿hall be the Ichnography. This Figure following is the Ichnography, that is, the ground of the Temple aforeÅ¿ayd, which is meaÅ¿ured by the ancient, or old RomiÅ¿h Palmes placed along by the Å¿ide hereof. And firÅ¿t, Å¿peaking of the Portall, whereof the Columnes are 6. Palmes & 29. minutes thicke. The Intercolumnes (which are the Å¿paces from one Columne to another) are 8. And although that the Chappels make the walles hollow, yet betweene them there are hollow places made within the walles, which Å¿ome Å¿ay, were left for places to receiue wind, becauÅ¿e of earthquakes. It is no wonder that Å¿uch and Å¿o old a piece of worke is yet whole and Å¿tanding Å¿till, for that the foundation was not Å¿paringly made; for it is thought that it was once as broad againe vnder as it is aboue, as it had beene found by the neighbour workemen: but let vs proceed to the particular meaÅ¿ure thereof from the earth vpwards. div.head: The inner part of the Temple or Pantheon.
div.p: THis Figure following Å¿heweth the Pantheon within, which forme (as I Å¿aid) is taken from Sphera, becauÅ¿e it is Å¿o wide from one wall vnto the other, as it is high from the Pauement to the open place vpon the top thereof; which wideneÅ¿Å¿e and height are both a hundred ninetie and foure Palmes vpwards, from the Pauement to the higheÅ¿t; and from the Cornice to the higheÅ¿t part of the roofe is alÅ¿o the Å¿ame meaÅ¿ure, that is, each the halfe of one hundred ninetie and foure Palmes. THis Ornament is yet Å¿tanding aboue the Portall of the Pantheon, which is made in this manner, all of Copper plates, the halfe Circle is not there; but there was a crooked Superficies finely made of Copper: and many men are of opinion that the beautifying thereof was of Siluer, for the reaÅ¿ons aforeÅ¿aid: but wherof it was, it is not well knowne; but it is true, it was excellent faire worke, conÅ¿idering that which is yet to bee Å¿Ã©ene.

THis Theater AuguÅ¿tus made in the name of Marcellus his Nephew, and therefore it was called Marcellus Theater, it Å¿tandeth within Rome, you may at this day Å¿ee part of it Å¿tanding vpright, that is part of the Galleries without: it is onely of two rules, that is, Dorica and Ionica, a worke, in truth, that is much commended, although the Doricall Columnes haue no BaÅ¿es, nor any Cinete or Proiecture vnder them, but Å¿tand playnely without any thing vnder, vpon the Å¿lat ground of the Gallery. div.p: IN Dalmatia there is an ancient town called Pola, lying by the Sea Å¿ide, wherin you may Å¿Ã©e a great part of a Theatre; in the making whereof, the expert workeman did helpe himÅ¿elfe with the hill whereon it Å¿tandeth, vÅ¿ing the hill for part of the degrÃ©es or Å¿teps to goe vp, and in the playne below, he made the OrcheÅ¿tra, Scene, and other buildings belonging to Å¿uch a piece of worke. div.head: The maner of Dorica, and the Ornaments thereof. The Å¿ixt Chapter.
div.p: THe Ancients (as we haue heard) conÅ¿idering the Å¿tate of their gods, ordained Dorica worke, and dedicated the Å¿ame to Iupiter, Mars, and Hercules: but we build Temples, and dedicate them to ChriÅ¿t, Paul, Gregory, and Å¿uch holy perÅ¿onages, that were not onely profeÅ¿Å¿ed Souldiers, but alÅ¿o valiantly and boldly loÅ¿t their liues, and Å¿hed their bloud for the faith of CHRIST. All Å¿uch belong to Dorica, and not to their gods onely, but to men of armes, and Å¿trong perÅ¿onages, being of qualitie more or leÅ¿Å¿e: for whom, if a workeman make or build houÅ¿es or palaces, they muÅ¿t be Dorica: and the nobler the man is for whom Å¿uch worke is done, the Å¿tronger and Å¿tatelyer they ought to be; and the more effeminate that they are, the more Å¿lenderer and pleaÅ¿anter the building Å¿hall be, as I will Å¿hew when time Å¿erueth. But now we will come to the maner of the worke. Vitruuius Å¿peaketh of this Dorica worke, in his fourth Booke and third Chapter: but touching BaÅ¿es of Columnes, hee Å¿peaketh thereof in his third Booke; although Å¿ome are of opinion, that he Å¿peaketh & meaneth of the BaÅ¿es of Corinthia, for that they haue bene much vÅ¿ed on the Corinthia Columnes, and Ionica. And Å¿ome alÅ¿o thinke, that Dorica Columnes had no BaÅ¿es, hauing reÅ¿pect to many ancient buildings; as the Theater of Marcellus, one of the fayreÅ¿t workes in Italy, being the middle downewards Dorica: which Columnes had no BaÅ¿es, the body of the Columnes reÅ¿ting vpon a Å¿tep, without any other Å¿upport. There is at Carcer Tulliano the Å¿ignes of a Doricall Temple, the Columnes whereof are without BaÅ¿es. You may alÅ¿o Å¿ee in Verona an Arch tryumphant, of Dorica worke, where the Columnes are without BaÅ¿es. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, for that workemen haue in former times made the Corinthia BaÅ¿es in another maner, as I will Å¿hew hereafter: Therefore I affirme, that the BaÅ¿es Atticurga, which Vitruuius, in his third Booke, Å¿o nameth, are the Dorica BaÅ¿es: and this wee Å¿ee, Bramant hath obÅ¿erued in his Buildings which he made in Rome: which Bramant, being the light and Inuentor of good and true Architecture, which from Antiquitie to his time (being vnder Pope Iulius the Å¿econd) had beene hidden, we ought to beleeue. Then this BaÅ¿e of Dorica Å¿hall be the height of halfe the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of a Columne: the Plinthus the third part of his height: of the reÅ¿t there Å¿halbe foure parts made; one Å¿hall be for the Thorus aboue: the other three Å¿hall be Å¿et in 3. euen parts: the one for the Thorus aboue, the Å¿econd for the Trochile or Scotia: but the Å¿ame being deuided in Å¿euen parts, one part Å¿hall be the vppermoÅ¿t liÅ¿t, and another the vndermoÅ¿t. The Proiecture or bearing out of the BaÅ¿e, Å¿hall be of halfe the height, and Å¿o Å¿hall the Plinthus of each Facie hold a thickneÅ¿Å¿e and a halfe of the Columne. And if the BaÅ¿e Å¿tandeth below our Å¿ight, the corner vnder the vppermoÅ¿t Thorus, (being of it Å¿elfe darkened) ought to bee Å¿omewhat lower then the other. But if the BaÅ¿e Å¿tandeth aboue our Å¿ight, the corner aboue the nethermoÅ¿t Thorus (alÅ¿o of it Å¿elfe darkened) Å¿hall be greater then the other. Thereto alÅ¿o the Scotia, darkened by the Thorus, in Å¿uch caÅ¿e Å¿halbe made more then the meaÅ¿ure appoynted. And in Å¿uch caÅ¿es the workeman muÅ¿t be iudicious and wary, as Vitruuius would haue him to bee learned in the Mathematicall Å¿cience, that doth Å¿tudy his Booke.

ANd for that Vitruuius hath deuided this order of Dorica by models, making the Columne of two models in thickneÅ¿Å¿e, and the height with Capitals and BaÅ¿es of 14. Models; Å¿o then, the height of the BaÅ¿e is a Modell: the bodie of the Columne is 12. models: and the Capitall one modell, which is 14. models in all: The height of the Capitall Å¿hall be deuided in 3. parts, whereof one Å¿hall be for the Plinthus, or Abacus, wherein alÅ¿o the Cimatie is to be vnderÅ¿tood: the Å¿econd, the Echino with the Annulo: the third, the Hypotrachilo or FrÃ©eÅ¿e, which Hypotrachilo Å¿hall bee in thickeneÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ixt part leÅ¿Å¿e then the Columne below. The bredth of the Capitall in the vppermoÅ¿t part Å¿hall be in each Facie 2. Models and a Å¿ixt part and this is according to Vitruuius wryting. Although I am of opinion, that this place is falÅ¿ifyed touching the Proiecture, which, in effect, is very lame, in reÅ¿pect of that we Å¿Ã©e in Antiquities; therefore, after this Capitall, I will make another after my fantaÅ¿ie, with the particular meaÅ¿ures thereof, better deÅ¿cribed, for that Vitruuius doeth it too briefly.

The Capitall being deuided into 3. partsâª as I Å¿ayd before, I Å¿ay alÅ¿o, that the Plinthus or Abacus Å¿hould alÅ¿o be deuided in 3. parts, one part for the Cimatie with her Rule, LiÅ¿t, or Fillet: but the Å¿ame thickneÅ¿Å¿e deuided in 3. Å¿hall bee the LiÅ¿t, and the other two the Cimatie. The Echinus Å¿hall alÅ¿o be deuided in 3. parts, and 2. third parts being for the Echinus, and the reÅ¿t for the Annulo, which Å¿hall alÅ¿o be deuided in 3. parts, giuing each of them one. The FrÃ©eÅ¿e Å¿hall bee as the others. The Proiecture of each part Å¿halbe like the height: and Å¿o doing, it Å¿hall bee made by more certaine rules, better, and more eaÅ¿ily for Å¿hew.

VPon the Capitall you place the EpiÅ¿tilia or Architraue, the height whereof Å¿hall be one Modell, and deuided in 7. parts, one Å¿hall be the Tenia or LiÅ¿t: the Guttes or Å¿mall LiÅ¿ts vnder the Tenia (which Vitruuius nameth Sub tenia) are in all, the Å¿ixt part of a modell: which height being deuided into 4. parts, the 3. parts Å¿hall bee the Guttes, and the other the LiÅ¿t. VpoÌ the Trigliphs, you muÅ¿t place their Capitals: the height whereof Å¿hall be one Å¿ixt part of a Modell. Aboue the Trigliphs or their Capitals, the Corona muÅ¿t bee placed with 2. Cimaties, the one aboue, the other below: and they both together deuided into 5. parts, 3. for the Corona, and two for the Cimaties. But the height of them all, Å¿halbe of halfe a Modell: vpon the Corona, you muÅ¿t place the Scima: the height whereof is halfe a Modell, and to it you muÅ¿t adde one eyght part for the LiÅ¿t thereof aboue. The Protecture of the Corona Å¿hall bee of 3. parts: two be in one Modell: in the ground of the Corona, right aboue the Trigliphes, the Guttes were orderly Å¿et, as you Å¿Ã©e them in the Figure hanging beÅ¿ide. But the more Proiecture the Corona hath, if the Å¿tone may beare it, the more Å¿tatelyer it Å¿heweth. This, we Å¿Ã©e, that the ancient Romanes did obÅ¿erue, as Å¿hall be Å¿hewed when time Å¿erueth, both in Figure and meaÅ¿ure.

IF you will Å¿tricke or channell the Columnes, you muÅ¿t make 20. in number, in maner hollowed, and from the one Å¿ide to the other: in the Å¿paces of the Å¿trikes there muÅ¿t a Å¿trayght line bee drawne, which Å¿hall bee the Å¿ide of one 4. Å¿quare: which 4. Å¿quare being made, placing the one foote of the Compas in the Center, and with the other touching both the one and the other end of the line, drawing it about, it will make the right hollowing, which Å¿hall be the fourth part of a Circle, as it is hÃ©ereunder Å¿hewed. Å¿quare; and from the one corner to the other, a line drawne for Diagonus, and the length of the Diagonus Å¿hall bee the height of the flat, as you may Å¿Ã©e it here beneath, which being deuided into 5. parts, there Å¿halbe one part Å¿et aboue for the Cimatie, with that belongeth therunto, and one other part Å¿halbe giuen to the BaÅ¿e; and Å¿o this PedeÅ¿tall Å¿halbe of 7. parts, as the Columne is. And although this Proiecture of the Capital is contrary to Vitruuius rule, becauÅ¿e it is Perpendicular with the Plintho of the BaÅ¿e: yet for that I haue Å¿Ã©ene the like in Å¿ome Antiquities, and haue alÅ¿o placed Å¿ome of the like Å¿ort in pieces of worke, I thought i â¢ not amiÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿et this hÃ©ere, for the vÅ¿e of â¢â¢ oÅ¿e, that will make ye like, although Å¿ome of Vitruuius Å¿chollers, not hauing Å¿Ã©ene the like in any Antiquities, will contradict it: but if they marke the Abacus of the Corinthia, whoÅ¿e Proiecture alÅ¿o hangeth on the Plinthus of the BaÅ¿e, they will not Å¿o haÅ¿tily reiect this Proiecture.

FOr that I find great difference betwÃ©ene the wrytings of Vitruuius, and the things of Rome, and other places of Italy; therefore I haue hÃ©ere Å¿et downe Å¿ome, which are yet extant in worke to be Å¿Ã©ene: which, although they bee of Å¿mall forme, without numbers or meaÅ¿ures, yet they are proportioned according to the great, and with great diligence reduced into Å¿mall forme. THe parts of the Trigliphes and Methophes being in this order vnprepared, and yet very neceÅ¿Å¿ary, I will take paynes to declare Å¿o well as I can. The middlemoÅ¿t Å¿halbe dealt thus, that the Å¿mall Columues Å¿hall be the halfe of the greater, and the middlemoÅ¿t inter-Columne Å¿halbe as broad againe as thoÅ¿e that Å¿tand on the Å¿ides, which Å¿hall be like eyes of the windowes. BEfore, I hane Å¿hewed in two figures, how to make the Facies or forefronts of HouÅ¿es after the Venetians maner: but for that in Å¿uch works men would willingly haue Å¿ome places bearing out, which are, for the moÅ¿t part, made ouer the water, for freÅ¿h ayre of the water, whereon the moÅ¿t part of buildings haue their fayreÅ¿t forefronts or Facies; as alÅ¿o, to Å¿Ã©e the tryumphes oftentimes made there in Boates and Ships: to which purpoÅ¿e, the Å¿ayd bearings or iuttyings out Å¿erue well, and yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, are vnÅ¿Ã©emely things, and haue no other Å¿upporters but the Mogdilions: Now, Å¿uch things as haue not their foundation Å¿trongly layd and made, hurt the walles of the houÅ¿e or building, whereof ancient workemen were very carefull, and made no Å¿uch bearing out, but onely Cornices: therefore I Å¿ay, if a man will make any Å¿uch things in any building with good aduice, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the firÅ¿t wall Å¿hould bee Å¿o thicke, that it may Å¿tand Å¿o farre out as the flat of the bearing out requireth, as may bee perceyued in the round: and for that the middlamoÅ¿t wall Å¿tandeth out more then the Å¿ides, if you will not make it Å¿o thicks, then you may make a Å¿trong Arch within, to vphold the middlemoÅ¿t, although it be hollow and of Å¿mall weyght. The height of this Å¿econd order or Å¿tory, Å¿hall be like the vndermoÅ¿t, according to the rules aforeÅ¿ayd: and firÅ¿t, you Å¿hall make the Podium of an indifferent height, to leane vpon: then that which reÅ¿teth Å¿hall be deuided in fiue parts, one of thoÅ¿e Å¿hall bee the EpiÅ¿tilium, with the reÅ¿t of his parts. The wideneÅ¿Å¿e of the middle moÅ¿t part, muÅ¿t be thus: the openneÅ¿Å¿e with the Arch muÅ¿t be as great agains as the Å¿ides, and the height doubled; Å¿o the Architraues being Å¿et vpon the Columnes, for the vpholding of the Arch, all the Wind â¢â¢â¢â¢ s Å¿hall bee vpon a rome: likewiÅ¿e alÅ¿o, for more commoditie of light and ornament, the eyes of the Wind â¢â¢â¢â¢â¢ Å¿hall bee made. TheÅ¿e ornaments, together with many other things, if a man, in regard of coÅ¿t, will not make them of Marble, or of other Å¿tones, they may be Å¿et foorth with painting. The third order or Å¿tory Å¿hall alÅ¿o bee a â¢â¢â¢â¢ th partleÅ¿Å¿e then the Å¿econd: and Å¿o euery other part thereof accordingly, following the rule aforeÅ¿ayd: and although the Ionica be Å¿et before the Dorica, which ancient worknen Å¿ome time haue done, you Å¿hall find the proportio â¢â¢

ALthough the workeman hath Å¿Ã©ene Å¿o many inuentions in this Dorica worke, yet they will not further him for ornaments of Chimneyes: but I will Å¿et two Å¿orts thereof here in Figure, one indifferent whole, & in the thickeneÅ¿Å¿e of the wall, for a Å¿mall round Chamber or HouÅ¿e: the other, for a greater place without the wall, drawne with Mogdilions: for if a Å¿mall Chamber Å¿hould be cumbred with a Chimney, it is requiÅ¿ite to make it wholy within the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of the wall, and the height of the opening being made, according to the Å¿ituation of the place, Å¿hall be deuided into foure parts and an halfe, and Å¿hall be the bredth of the PilaÅ¿ter, but the Architraue Å¿hall containe the halfe: the Tenia or LiÅ¿t, going round about, Å¿hall bee a Å¿euenth part, and all his other LiÅ¿ts of the Å¿ame bredth: the Trigliphes and Mogdilions, Å¿hall be halfe the bredth of the Architraue, but their height you Å¿hall take in this manner, that the Mutiles Å¿tand aboue the PilaÅ¿ters, and the Trigliphes deuided betwÃ©ene both, the Methopes may haue their foureÅ¿quare of the bredth of the Architraue, but yet the Methopes or Å¿paces betwixt the Mogdilions, Å¿hall not bee foureÅ¿quare. The Capitals of the Mutiles and Trigliphes, Å¿hall bee Å¿o high as halfe the bredth of the Trigliphes. The Corona, with the Scimatie and Scima, Å¿hall bee Å¿o high as the Architraue; and being deuides in two parts, one part Å¿hall be for the Corona; of the other you muÅ¿t make thrÃ©e parts, one for the Cimatie with the LiÅ¿t, the other Å¿hall be for the Scima with his LiÅ¿t. The bearing out of the Corona Å¿hall be Å¿o great or little, that the Å¿paces betwÃ©ene the Capitals of the Trigliphes in the ground of the Corona, may be foureÅ¿quare, for that, if men will Å¿it round about it, they may haue their place of Å¿ight. THis other Chimney without the wall, Å¿hall be made thus, when the height and wideneÅ¿Å¿e of the place, according to the Å¿ituation, is appoynted, the Å¿ame height, from the ground vp to the Architraue, Å¿hall be deuided in 4. parts, one part for the Architcaue, FreeÅ¿e, & Cornice, their parts being made according to the rule aforeÅ¿ayd: and whereas they Å¿hew greater, that is, becauÅ¿e men Å¿Ã©e them vnderneath, the bredth of the Modiglions Å¿hall be the 7. part of their height: the Capitals the halfe of that bredth, and Å¿halbe deuided as it is Å¿aid of the Doricall Capitals: Å¿ome leÅ¿Å¿en the bredths of theÅ¿e Modiglions vnderneath the fourth part, that the foote of them may giue out a fourth part, Å¿o that the Plinthus vnder the foote, is as broad as the vppermoÅ¿t part. But if you will make Å¿uch Modiglions all of one bredth, I would commend it in a great worke, for that the vndermoÅ¿t drawing to the wall, & going from our Å¿ight, leÅ¿Å¿en themÅ¿elues: for that the part which receaueth the Å¿moke, is Piramides-wiÅ¿e, which wil not Å¿tand well in a great height. div.head: Of the order of Ionica, and the Ornaments thereof. The Å¿euenth Chapter.
div.p: VItruuius Å¿peaketh of Ionica, in his fourth Booke and 1. Chapter: and as I alÅ¿o Å¿aid, the ancient Pagans tooke this kind of worke from women, and aÅ¿cribed it to Diana, Apollo, & Bacchus, &c. But we that are ChriÅ¿tians, hauing a Temple to make of this worke, we will dedicate it to Å¿uch Saints as are of nature, eyther weake or Å¿trong: Å¿o likewiÅ¿e, common workes are fit for peaceable people, men, neyther great workemen, nor all too Å¿imple in workemanÅ¿hip: and Å¿uch workemen are fitteÅ¿t for Å¿uch worke. Now let vs come to the meaÅ¿ures: the Ionica Columne, by a common rule, muÅ¿t be of 8. parts, with Capitall and BaÅ¿e: although that Vitruuius Å¿ayth, it muÅ¿t be of 8. parts and an halfe; Å¿o may men Å¿ometimes make it of 9. parts and more, as Å¿ome indifferent workemen haue affirmed. But this, I Å¿ay, Å¿hall be made of 8. parts, which muÅ¿t hold his thickneÅ¿Å¿e below, and Å¿o Å¿hall their BaÅ¿es be of halfe the Å¿ame thickenes, which Vitruuius Å¿etteth downe diligently, in the 3. Booke, and in the third Chapter of the Å¿ame Booke, in this maner, that the BaÅ¿e aforeÅ¿ayd, muÅ¿t be of halfe the Columnes thickeneÅ¿Å¿e, but the Plinthus muÅ¿t be of the third part thereof: which Plinthus taken of, you Å¿hal make Å¿euen parts of the reÅ¿t; whereof three Å¿hall be for the Thorus, and foure Å¿hall bee for the two Scoties or Trochiles, with their AÅ¿tragals and LiÅ¿ts, Å¿o that each Trochile muÅ¿t haue his AÅ¿tragall. The AÅ¿tragall Å¿hall be the eyght part of the Trochile, the LiÅ¿ts halfe the AÅ¿tragals. Although each Scotie with the Appendances are all of one height, yet the vndermoÅ¿t Å¿halbe greater; for it Å¿hall Å¿hoot out vnderneath, to the outtermoÅ¿t part of the Plinthus. The Proiecture on eyther Å¿ide, Å¿hall be one eyght part, and one fixt part: Å¿o that the Plinthus on eyther Å¿ide Å¿hall be one fourth part, and one eyght part more then the thickeneÅ¿Å¿e of the Columnes. Now, for that the Cincte or LiÅ¿t is Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed by the greatnes of the Thorus, I am perÅ¿waded that it ought to be made the halfe greater then the other. ObÅ¿erue in all the members and parts with diÅ¿cretion, as Å¿hould be vÅ¿ed in the Dorica.

FOR that the BaÅ¿e of the Ionica Pillar, written of by Vitruuius, contenteth not the greateÅ¿t workemen, becauÅ¿e the Thorus is very great, and the AÅ¿tragall Å¿mall, vnder Å¿o great a member, according to the iudgement of expert workmen, that haue oftentimes diÅ¿puted the Å¿ame, with reuerence, and much reÅ¿pect of Å¿uch an Author; I will frame one here according to my opinion. The Plinthus being made, as I Å¿ayd before, the reÅ¿t Å¿halbe deuided in thrÃ©e parts, whereof one part Å¿halbe for the Thorus: the other vnder that Thorus deuide in Å¿ixe parts; one of them for an AÅ¿tragall, the Cinthe the halfe thereof. The Cinthe or Supercilie vnder the
Thorus, muÅ¿t be as broad as the AÅ¿tragall. The reÅ¿t is for the Scotie or Trochile: the other thrÃ©e parts that reÅ¿t, Å¿hall alÅ¿o be deuided into Å¿ire parts: one for the AÅ¿tragall, one halfe for the Cinthe, and the vndermoÅ¿t alÅ¿o the like: the reÅ¿t is for the Scotio comming at vnderneath, as is before alleaged.

THe Ionica Capitall Å¿hall bee made in this maner: the height Å¿hall be the third part of a Columne, and the former part of ye Abacus the bredth of a Columne in thicknes: to it alÅ¿o muÅ¿t be added the 18. part, which in the whole, Å¿hall be ninetÃ©ene parts, but inwards a part and a halfe: at eyther end the line Catheta muÅ¿t be drawne, which Å¿hall containe 9. parts and an halfe, which is the halfe bredth of the Capitall: one part and a halfe Å¿halbe for the Abacus, which Corners you muÅ¿t make like the right or left Å¿ide, for both are ancient: the 8. parts that are hanging vnder the Abacus, Å¿hall be for the Volutes. And for that it would be troubleÅ¿ome in this Å¿mall Figure, eÅ¿pecially to Å¿et downe before your eyes the numbers, therfore in the LeaÅ¿e following, I will Å¿hew it better in great, and therewithall the maner how to make the Å¿trickes in the Columnes, with the Figure of the Å¿ide of the Volutes, and of the Capitals. But if the Columne be of 15. foote downwards, then it Å¿hall be leÅ¿Å¿ened a Å¿ixt part aboue, as it is written of the ThuÅ¿can order: but if it bee of 15. foote vpwards, then I referre you to Vitruuius, touching the Å¿ame, in his third Booke and Å¿econd Chapter.

WHEN the Capitall of this Ionica is made, you muÅ¿t make the Volutes, which Å¿hall bee made by the line, called Catheta, which wee heere call, The right Lead: and when you leaue the Abacus vnderneath foure parts, then the firÅ¿t part Å¿hall be for the eye, and Å¿o there yet reÅ¿teth thrÃ©e parts from the eye downe wards; and Å¿o in all, they make eyght, as is before Å¿ayd: the eye Å¿hall be deuided in Å¿ixe parts, and the numbers Å¿et therein, as it is here Å¿et downe; then place one foote of the Compas vpon the poynt 1. and the other foot vnder the Abacus, drawing nether ward, vp to the Catheta, to the eyght part; then letting the Å¿ame foote of the CompaÅ¿Å¿e Å¿tand, bring the other foot of the CompaÅ¿Å¿e to 2. and draw it vpwards againe to the Catheta. Then hold the foot of the CompaÅ¿Å¿e there, bringing the other foote to 3. drawing it then downe wards againe to the Catheta: kÃ©eping that foote there alÅ¿o, bring the other vpon the poynt 4. then drawing it againe to the Catheta, holding the CompaÅ¿Å¿e there, the foot will come vpon 5. Å¿o drawing about, doe likewiÅ¿e to 6. and then it comes to Å¿hut with the eye; there you may make a roofe, it you pleaÅ¿e. The reÅ¿t of the particular members you Å¿hall eaÅ¿ily find with the CompaÅ¿Å¿e. The Å¿trickes of the Columnes, which wee call Chanels or hollowings, Å¿hall be 24. in number, and one of them Å¿hall be 5. parts: whereof 4. Å¿hall be for the Guttes or Chanels, and the 5. for the LiÅ¿t, by Vitruuius called Strix: and Å¿o from one Å¿ide of the flat of the LiÅ¿t to the other, you Å¿hall draw a Å¿trayght line, the middle whereof Å¿hall be the Center of the hollowing out. But if the workeman pleaÅ¿e Å¿ometimes to make a thinne Columne to Å¿hew thicke, then there muÅ¿t bee 28. Å¿trickes: the Abacus of this Capitall is as broad on the Å¿ides, as before: which Å¿ides are proportioned according to that, which is Å¿ayd before. Friendly Reader, I haue layd this Volute, according to my Å¿imple vnderÅ¿tanding, becauÅ¿e Vitruuius writing is hard to vnderÅ¿tand, and which is more, promiÅ¿ed the Å¿ame Figure in the laÅ¿t Booke, together, with diuers other ornaments, which Booke is not to bee found.

div.head: S. Serlii vpon the Å¿peach aforeÅ¿ayd.
div.p: LOuing Reader, there are many things which cannot fully, from poynt to poynt, bee Å¿hewed in Figure, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the workeman muÅ¿t helpe himÅ¿elfe by practiÅ¿e, like as the Cincte or band of theÅ¿e Volutes: which (if the Capitall bee very great) will Å¿tand well: if the bredth contayneth the fourth part of the eye, and if the Capitall bee of indifferent greatneÅ¿Å¿e, then it muÅ¿t be made of a third part of the eye: but if the Capitall be Å¿mall, then it muÅ¿t bee the halfe of the eye, alwayes at the workemans diÅ¿cretion: for I haue Å¿Ã©ene it Å¿o in Antiquities, although they differ. The thickneÅ¿Å¿e being marked aboue, vnder the Abacus, then you muÅ¿t place the CompaÅ¿Å¿e a little below the figure 1. from aboue the Catheta downe wards: then agayne, you muÅ¿t place the CompaÅ¿Å¿e a little aboue the figure 2. drawing your line from beneath vpwards to the Catheta.

Now, whereas I haue Å¿ayd, that the laÅ¿t Booke promiÅ¿ed by Vitruuius, is not found, by meanes whereof, diuers opinions are Å¿pred abroad touching the Å¿ame, Å¿ome affirming, that in Vitruuius time, there were many vnÅ¿kilfull workemen (as there are now alÅ¿o) hauing better fortune, then good vnderÅ¿tanding: (others) that preÅ¿umption, Å¿iÅ¿ter to vnÅ¿kilfulneÅ¿Å¿e, beareth Å¿uch Å¿way among common workemen, that vnderÅ¿tand not themÅ¿elues, it is thought, that Vitruuius refuÅ¿ed, or at leaÅ¿t, would not publiÅ¿h it, in regard of the vnthankfulneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿uch as neglect good learning. Some alÅ¿o affirme, that it was too hard a matter for him to place them in figures; which I can hardly iudge to bee the mind of Å¿uch an Author. But whereas Å¿ome affirme, that this laÅ¿t Booke was Å¿o pleaÅ¿ing and acceptable, in regard of the figures there at large Å¿et out, and he being ouer-carefull in looking vnto it, was robbed thereof, among other riches and treaÅ¿ures, by vnÅ¿kilfull perÅ¿ons: this I belÃ©eue beÅ¿t, is as warre, which is enemy to all good Artes, which yet, at this day, is eÅ¿pecially to be lamented, for that men by the figures, might haue made diuerÅ¿ities of worke in the right maner.

I Haue declared hereafter, according to Vitruuius writing, how to make Ionica worke, as farre as my learning Å¿hall Å¿erue. Now, I will Å¿hew how Å¿ome Antiquities in Rome, of that worke, are made, yet Å¿tanding. The Capitall M. Å¿tandeth yet in the Theater of Marcellus, whereof I will Å¿et downe Å¿ome general meaÅ¿ures: the forehead of this Abacus is like vnto the Columne below. The Volutes giue out a Å¿ixt part of the Abacus, and Å¿o farre out as the halfe of the Abacus: the height of the Capitall is a third part of the Columne below; but for that Å¿ome workemen thought that Capitall to be but barely Å¿et foorth, they haue added the FrÃ©eÅ¿e which you Å¿Ã©e in the Capitall, vnto it, making the height of the Capitall of 2. third parts, of the Columnes thickeneÅ¿Å¿e below, which Capital is at this day to bee Å¿Ã©ene in Rome, with others of the like.

ANd for that it may Å¿ometimes happen to the workeman, to make a foureÅ¿quare Å¿hutting with Ionica Capitals, Å¿o that Å¿ome workmen haue erred in placing of the Volutes; to helpe or caÅ¿e you of that errour, it Å¿halbe nÃ©edfull to make the corner Capitals, as you Å¿Ã©e them in this ground: of Å¿uch Capitals, there was the like found in Rome, which cauÅ¿ed many to Å¿tudy, where it was made, in Å¿uch maner, for it was called, The confuÅ¿ed Capitall: but at laÅ¿t, after long diÅ¿putation, it was concluded, that it had Å¿tood in an open corner, Å¿hutting vp the order of the Columnes marked A. But if the workeman haue flat Columnes to place againÅ¿t the wall, in this Corner, that the Volutes may come alike on both Å¿ides, the workeman may place them, as in the ground B. is Å¿et downe.

THe EpiÅ¿tilium or Architraue is made thus: If the Columne be of 12. to 15. foote high, the Architraue Å¿halbe the halfe of the Columne beneath: if it be of 15. to 20. foote high, then it Å¿halbe deuided in 13. parts: one Å¿halbe the height of the Architraue; and from 20. to 25. foote, the Columne Å¿hall be deuided in 12. parts and a halfe: one part Å¿halbe giuen to the Architraue: If the Columne be of 25. to 30. foote high, then the EpiÅ¿tilium Å¿hall be the twelfth part of that height: It the Columne be higher, you muÅ¿t increaÅ¿e the Architraue more: for the further it goeth from a mans Å¿ight, Å¿o much â¢â¢â¢ re it loÅ¿eth of the greatneÅ¿Å¿e. The Architraue being made of his due light, and deuided in 7. one Å¿halbe the Cimatie: the Proiecture thereof, alÅ¿o as great. That which is ouer, is deuided in 12. thrÃ©e Å¿halbe giuen to the firÅ¿t Facies, foure to the Å¿econd, and fiue to the third. The thickneÅ¿Å¿e of the Architraue vnder, Å¿halbe like the Columne aboue, in the thinneÅ¿t part: but the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of the Architraue aboue, Å¿halbe like the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of the Columne below. The Zophorus or FrÃ©eÅ¿e Å¿hall haue the meaÅ¿ure according to the length of the worke: but if there be Å¿omewhat to cut or graue in it, then it muÅ¿t be made a fourth part higher then the Architraue: but if it be made playne, without cutting or grauing, then it muÅ¿t be a fourth part leÅ¿Å¿e. The Cimatie muÅ¿t be Å¿et vpon the FrÃ©eÅ¿e, which muÅ¿t be the Å¿euenth part of the Å¿ame FrÃ©eÅ¿e: and the proiecture alÅ¿o as much. Aboue the Cimatie muÅ¿t the Denticules be placed, in height, like the middlemoÅ¿t Facie: and the Proiecture like the height. The bredth of their tÃ©eth muÅ¿t be double in height. The intercutting or hollowing betwÃ©ene the tÃ©eth, Å¿halbe a third part leÅ¿Å¿e. The Cimatie is the Å¿ixt part of the Dentile. The Corona, with the Cimatie thereof, is the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the middlemoÅ¿t Facie. The Proiecture of the Corona, with the Denticules, is as much as the height of the FrÃ©eÅ¿e, with the Cimatie. The Scima is an eyght part higher then the Corona. The rule or liÅ¿t thereof Å¿hall be a Å¿ixt part, and the Proiecture like the height. FOr that the works of Rome differ from the writing of Vitruuius, I will frame another Columne, whereof the Architraue, FrÃ©eÅ¿e and Cornice, Å¿hall be the fourth part of the height of the Columne: which 4. part deuided in 10. parts, thrÃ©e Å¿hall be for the Architraue, deuided after the rule aforeÅ¿ayd: 3. for the FrÃ©eÅ¿e, and 4. for the Cornices: which 4. Å¿hall bee deuided in 6. whereof one Å¿hall be giuen to the Denticules, one to the Cimatie which vpholdeth the Mutiles, and two to the Mutiles and the Corona; the reÅ¿t to the Scima. The Proiecture of all, Å¿hall beat leaÅ¿t as much as the height: vpon Å¿uch a Cornice was four written, A Sante Sabina, at Rome, in a building of the order of Ionica.

ANd if Å¿ometimes it be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to rayÅ¿e vp Columnes, being not compelled or pinched by any thing thereabout, then the proportion of ye PedeÅ¿tal Å¿hall be thus; it Å¿hall be as broad before as the Plinthus of the Columne: but the height of the flat of the PedeÅ¿tall Å¿halbe a foureÅ¿quare, and a fourth part: which deuided in Å¿ixe parts, one Å¿hall be for the BaÅ¿e, and one for the Cornice, which in all is eyght parts: Å¿o Å¿hall the PedeÅ¿tal be of eyght parts like the Columne. div.p: HAuing Å¿poken of Å¿o many and diuers Ornaments of Å¿tones, it is requiÅ¿ite, that I Å¿hould alÅ¿o Å¿hew how they are to be placed in worke; and Å¿pecially, when a man is to mixe hard Å¿tones & bricks together, which requireth great diligence and Arte: for that bricks are like fleÅ¿h in a pÃ©ece of worke, and hard Å¿tones like the bones to knit and hold them together: which two things, if they be not well and faÅ¿tly bound together, they will, in time, decay: and therefore the foundation being made in Å¿uch maner as the place affordeth, it is requiÅ¿ite, that the prouident workeman Å¿hould make ready, all the hard Å¿tones, and alÅ¿o the bricks, with the reÅ¿t of the Å¿tuffe belonging thereunto, and Å¿o Å¿hould come to lay and ioyne the hard Å¿tones and the bricks together, all at one time: and it is requiÅ¿ite, that the hard Å¿tones Å¿hould be Å¿et Å¿o farre within the wall, that although there were no morter to hold them together, yet they Å¿hould, of themÅ¿elues, Å¿tand faÅ¿t in the wall: which doing, the worke will be Å¿trong and continue hard. But if the Columnes bee of one pÃ©ece, them they would Å¿tand, at leaÅ¿t, a third part within the wall; but the BaÅ¿es and Capitals muÅ¿t enter much more into the wall, and aboue all the Corona and other Cornices, which beare farre out from the wall. The innermoÅ¿t part that is vnwrought, muÅ¿t counteruayle that which is without, that it may beare it Å¿elfe: but if at the Å¿ame time a man will make any worke or Facie vpon the Å¿tones, then it is requiÅ¿ite, that the workeman, before he begins to lay any worke aboue the ground, Å¿hould make ready all his Å¿tones, together with the other Å¿tuffe belonging thereunto: and Å¿o laying and knitting the Å¿tones with the bricks together, I Å¿ay, that he Å¿hall doe well to Å¿et Å¿ome of the Å¿tones Å¿o dÃ©epe into the wall, that they may hold the other pÃ©eces together by force, ioyning well in, as you Å¿Ã©e it in the figure C. that in time they may not ryue and breake aÅ¿under one from the other. But that the wall, made of bricke, Å¿hould not Å¿inke, and Å¿inking, Å¿hould breake the thinneÅ¿t parts, by reaÅ¿on of the waight aboue, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to haue bricke well burnt, and morter well tempered, & betwÃ©ene the Å¿tones little morter, & wel layd and ioyned one vpon the other: And aboue all, Å¿uch worke would not be made by any force, nor waight vpon waight, to be packt in haÅ¿te, but you muÅ¿t let it reÅ¿t Å¿omewhat from lay to lay: for if a man wil worke in haÅ¿te, and Å¿et great waight vpon it, it is moÅ¿t certayne, the wall will Å¿inke, and the Å¿tones being not able to beare Å¿he waight, will breake; but if it be made with leyÅ¿er, then the Å¿tuffe will be as it Å¿hould be: neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, I would alwayes more commend the worke that is wholy bound in the wall, then that which is ioyned together or couered; and Å¿pecially, in my opinion, men Å¿hould not make them in walles that Å¿tand outward, for that the houÅ¿es which haue bÃ©ene made Å¿o in former time, by ancient workemen, and were couered ouer with Marble and other fine Å¿tones, are now Å¿Ã©ene all without Å¿tones before, and nothing but the wall of bricke, that Å¿tood behind them, Å¿tandeth Å¿till: but thoÅ¿e buildings, where the hard Å¿tones are bound and ioyned into, and with the bricks, are yet Å¿tanding: neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, if you will make Å¿uch worke Å¿imple, I thinke this the Å¿ureÅ¿t way, although Å¿ome workemen, in diuers places of Italy, haue made Å¿ome building, with Å¿imple walles, leauing places in them for hard Å¿tones to be put in, and after, at another time, haue put in Å¿uch Ornaments: neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, for that Å¿uch things are not well faÅ¿tened in the wall, but in a maner hackt, you may in many places Å¿Ã©e the pÃ©eces falne, and euery day more and more decay.

div.p: ALthough wee Å¿ee and find diuers formes of Temples and Churches in ChriÅ¿tendome, as well ancient as moderne, yet for that I haue formerly promiÅ¿ed to Å¿hew Å¿ome Orders thereof, to accompliÅ¿h the number of my Bookes, therefore I will intreat of them, and Å¿et downe twelue Å¿euerall maner of Temples, with their grounds and meaÅ¿ures: and for that the round forme is the perfiteÅ¿t of all others, therefore I will begin with it: but though in our time, whether it be by reaÅ¿on of Å¿mall deuotion, or cruelty of men, there are no more great Churches begun to be made, and that men finiÅ¿h not them which in former time haue beene begun, therefore I will make mine Å¿o Å¿mall, as they may paÅ¿Å¿e in reaÅ¿onable maner, for that with Å¿mall coÅ¿t, they might in Å¿hort time be made.
